subject: Outreachy 2021
header: If you remember, I mentioned Outreachy program in the editorial of the weekly newsletter edition #522. It has finally come to an end as Rosheen Naeem successfully completed the internship as reported by the TPF in the blog. Congratulation Rosheen.
The Perl Foundation is looking for mentors and project ideas for the next Outreachy rounds. If you have Perl or Raku project ideas, please get in touch with TPF.

Many years ago, I was reached out for help by the Open Food Facts team as they found out about my distribution, Food::ECodes. Unfortunately it didn't work out as I was too busy with my other pet projects. I hope one day I can contribute to Open Food Facts. I remember I had trouble setting up local development environment for contribution. I haven't had chance to see if any improvement done in this regard to help newcomers to contribute.
I request Perl fans to come forward and help the cool fun project Open Food Facts.
Enjoy rest of the newsletter and stay safe.

entries.author: mohammad_anwar
entries.text: Time for monthly report, little late though.

chapters.title: The Weekly Challenge
chapters.header: The Weekly Challenge by Mohammad Anwar will help you step out of your comfort-zone. You can even win prize money of $50 Amazon voucher by participating in the weekly challenge. We pick one winner at the end of the month from among all of the contributors during the month. The monthly prize is kindly sponsored by Peter Sergeant of PerlCareers.

entries.author: mohammad_anwar
entries.text: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Consecutive Arrays" and "Find Pairs". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.
entries.title: The Weekly Challenge - 131

entries.author: mohammad_anwar
entries.text: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Odd Number" and "Binary Search Tree" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.
entries.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 130

entries.text: I love the fact Perl solution looks like Raku and not the other way. Nice attempt.

entries.text: Ian is on declarative coding kick and enjoying Tree task. Keep it up.
entries.title: Perl Weekly Challenge Club - 130

entries.author: james_smith
entries.text: Nice use of bit operator to deal with Odd Number task. Cool hack to flatten the tree before checking if it is BST.
entries.title: Perl Weekly Challenge #130

entries.author: laurent_rosenfeld
entries.text: Laurent use of Bag to solve Odd Number gives us clean one-liner. For BST, recursive function is used.
entries.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 130: Odd Number and Binary Search Tree

entries.author: luca_ferrari
entries.text: I hate trees with a passion! sums up all the emotion by Luca. However we still got clean Raku code.
entries.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 130: quick

entries.text: For the first, Luis, used YAML for tree representation. It made the search really fun.

chapters.title: Perl Tutorial
chapters.header: A section for newbies and for people who need some refreshing of their Perl knowledge. If you have questions or suggestions about the articles, let me know and I'll try to make the necessary changes. The included articles are from the Perl Maven Tutorial and are part of the Perl Maven eBook.
